Heartfelt gratitude to my co-host, @SenTinaSmith, Dr. Rob Thomas of EPPA, Lisa Shannon of @AllinaHealth, Dr. Kelly Searle of @UMNews + 1,000s of Minnesotans for joining our coronavirus briefing call. We shared info, answered q‚Äôs and feel blessed to represent our remarkable state.

Lisa Shannon, @AllinaHealth COO:

"Remember that social distancing is physical distancing. We are not asking you to isolate - phone people, video chat. We can do this together. Reach out and support one another without being physically near one another. We can slow the spread."

Lisa Shannon, @AllinaHealth COO:

"We have to slow the spread because we don't want patients to transmit this illness and we need to make sure clinicians are available to take care of people with heart disease, cancer, and coronavirus."

Dr. Kelly Searle, @UMNews epidemiologist:

"This is unprecedented, a global pandemic, and very serious. We are working together to get through this, but it is different than anything we've seen - a 5 day incubation means people can transmit before they are aware they're sick."

Dr. Rob Thomas, Emergency Physician: 

"The evidence is showing that if someone is 71 and in good health, they are still at increased risk for this disease. Everyone in the population is susceptible to this infection, but the immune system weakens as we age."

Dr. Kelly Searle, @UMNews epidemiologist:

"You should cancel your travel plans. COVID-19 can travel quickly and efficiently through people. Whether you feel healthy or not, when we decrease our network and immediate contacts, we are decreasing who we can spread to."

Lisa Shannon, @AllinaHealth COO:

"If you feel symptoms, remove yourself from other people. Call your doctor before you get in the car. This protects you and health care providers from getting into an environment where exposure can happen."

Dr. Rob Thomas, Emergency Physician: 

"Common symptoms for coronavirus might feel early on like the common cold. It starts with a sore throat, sometimes a fever, and deeper into the illness a shortness of breath can develop."

Dr. Kelly Searle, @UMNews epidemiologist:

"Surfaces such as mail and deliveries can have the virus on them if touched by infected individuals. The virus can remain for up to 24 hours on cardboard. Wash your hands afterhandling mail and packages."

Dr. Kelly Searle, @UMNews epidemiologist:

"#COVID19 has shown to be incredibly transmissible. The curve is growing. When we talk about physical and social distancing we are talking about breaking the chain of transimissions to reduce the number of cases in our community." https://t.co/KF8rgazXH4

This requires ‚Äúsocial distancing‚Äù, the slowing of social contact by eliminating physical greetings, postponing public events and large gatherings, providing paid sick leave, and encouraging teleworking. And of course, wash hands regularly and stay home if you‚Äôre sick. 2/3
